correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p:
NAZARETH, in Galilee, now al-Nasira, the city of Mary and Joseph, and the place where our Lord spent his youth, is pleasantly situated in a hollow on the south slope of the hills (J. al-Sikh) which bound the plain of Esdraelon on the north. Though it had a synagogue (Matt, xiii. 54; Luke iv. 16), and is called in the Gospels a city, Nazareth
must have been an obscure place
Even the form of the name is uncertain, Nαfαpeτ, Nafap∈0, Naζapd. These variations are intelligible in a Hebrew or Syriac name with fem. termination, but hardly enable us to fix the original form. In Syriac and Arabic the £ is transcribed as sharp s; thus the root of the name Nazareth would be n-s-r, and so many ancients and moderns suppose that in Matt. ii. 23 the prophecy referred to is that of the Branch (néser) in Isa. xi. 1. in the time of Jesus, for we find no mention of it outside of the New Testament till Eusebius and Jerome identify it with a “village” which undoubtedly occupied the place of the modern Nasira. In Jerome’s time it was already visited by pilgrims, but as yet we hear nothing of relics or places associated with special incidents in the life of Jesus. The population was mainly Jewish,—exclusively so, we are told by Epiphanius, down to the time of Constantine,—and the Jews, after their manner in modern as in ancient times, seem to have been the inventors of various marvellous relics and identifications which were palmed off upon Christian pilgrims in the 6th century. Such at least is the natural inference from what Antoninus Martyr tells of these wonderfully friendly and communicative Hebrews. A century later Arculphus describes two great churches corresponding to the modern Greek church over the Virgin’s Well and the Latin church of the Franciscan monastery over the Grotto of the Annunciation. The place has since passed through various vicissitudes; it was most flourishing in the time of the crusaders, who transferred to it the bishopric of Scythopolis. The Ottomans at length expelled the Christians; but the Franciscans established themselves under the protection of Fakhr al-Din in 1620. The town has now a Greek, a Latin, and a Moslem quarter, as well as a Protestant mission and orphanage. The population is variously estimated at from 6000 to 10,000.

The Virgin’s Well, just outside the town, must have been frequented by the women of ancient as of modern Nazareth; all the other traditional sites are highly dubious. But this hardly affects the interest attaching to the town, for the character of Nazareth must at all times have depended on its position and surroundings. It was a little country town of peasants and handicraftsmen, nestling in olive groves and green meadows, separated and yet not distant from the busy life of the greater Galilaean cities, surrounded on all sides by the pleasantest landscapes of Canaan. The hill above the town commands one of the finest views in Galilee, from Hermon to Mount Carmel.
